net.letscode.game.misc

Class QuadTree<T extends QuadTreeItem>

  • java.lang.Object
    • net.letscode.game.misc.QuadTree<T>
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    Iterable<T>

    public class QuadTree<T extends QuadTreeItem>
extends Object
implements Iterable<T>
    Implements a 'static' Quadtree, a variation of a data structure used to aid in locating entities (or groups of entities) within 2D space. For rough details on this implementation, see the Wikipedia article.

    This implementation makes a few modifications to the standard algorithm, mainly in that the initial boundry size is static, and all subdivisions are exactly in half. That is, all subtrees are of a predetermined size.

    The final subtree, at MAX_DEPTH is special in that it is the only subtree that should contain QuadTreeItem instances

    Note that when iterating over this tree, items are only guaranteed to be ordered within [axis] / 2^(maxDepth) units. This structure is intended primarily for filtering groups of entities within a region, and should not be used for anything that requires accurate positioning.

    For the 3-dimensional equivalent, an Octree should be used instead.

    Author:
    timothyb89

    • Constructor Detail

      • QuadTree

        public QuadTree(Boundry2D boundry,
        int maxDepth)

      • QuadTree

        public QuadTree(double x,
        double y,
        double width,
        double height,
        int maxDepth)
        Creates a new QuadTree with the given boundry and maximum depth. Note that the maximum depth directly affects the accuracy of the tree, and a maximum depth that is too small will result in excessively coarse entity organization.
        Parameters:
        x - the boundry x
        y - the boundry y
        width - the boundry width
        height - the boundry height
        maxDepth - the maximum depth for the quadtree

      • QuadTree

        public QuadTree(QuadTree parent,
        QuadTree.Quadrant quadrant)
        Creates a new QuadTree for the given quadrant within the parent. The boundry is calculated based on the parent and the specified quadrant.
        Parameters:
        parent - the parent tree
        quadrant - the quadrant

    • Method Detail

      • getSubtree

        public QuadTree<T> getSubtree(QuadTree.Quadrant q)
        Gets the subtree for the given quadrant. Note that this will return null for empty subtrees, assuming that they have been pruned.
        Parameters:
        q - the quadrant
        Returns:
        the subtree for the given quadrant, or null

      • setSubtree

        public void setSubtree(QuadTree.Quadrant q,
              QuadTree tree)
        Sets the given subtree to the provided value.
        Parameters:
        q - the quadrant to set
        tree - the value to set for the given quadrant

      • insert

        public void insert(T item)
        Inserts the given item into the tree. Any necessary subtrees will be created, up to maxDepth.
        Parameters:
        item - the item to insert

      • remove

        public void remove(T item)
        Removes the given item from this tree. The tree is then pruned, nullifying trees emptied as a result of the removal.

        In particular, this will work on any item contained even within sibling trees, as this method (for indirect parents) just removes the child from the parent using item.getQuadTreeParent().remove(). This ends up being cheaper to do than searching subtrees for the real parent, and is also somewhat more lenient.

        Note that this method technically works with any QuadTreeItem, but is restricted to items within the same overall tree (i.e. same root tree).

        Parameters:
        item - the item to remove

      • update

        public void update(T item)
        Updates the given item. If the item's position has changed sufficiently for its parent quadrant to no longer contain it, it is removed and reinserted into the correct quadrant. Otherwise, nothing is changed.

        Note that all items are inserted from the root of the tree.

        Items that have no parent are inserted anyway.

        Parameters:
        item - the item to update

      • isEmpty

        public boolean isEmpty()
        Checks that this quadtree contains no children. This will call the respective isEmpty() methods of any non-null subtrees.
        Returns:
        true if this tree and its subtrees contain no children, false if at least one does

      • getChildren

        public List<T> getChildren()
        Returns an unmodifiable list of children contained (directly) within this QuadTree. Note that this specifically only direct children; the tree can be iterated over if a list of all children is needed.

        This should always return null for QuadTrees that are already at the maximum depth.

        Returns:
        an unmodifiable list of direct children for this tree

      • iterator

        public Iterator<T> iterator()
        Specified by:
        iterator in interface Iterable<T extends QuadTreeItem>

        public static void main(String[] args)
